channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Poll of British Muslims Reveals Startling Views, but Some Question Methodology
item.description: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Muslim men at the Baitul Futuh Mosque in London. A new poll revealed views among Britain’s largest religious minority that differed from the greater population’s.

item.title: Chacha the Chimp Escapes Japanese Zoo, Then Takes a Fall
item.description: A video shows the capture of a chimpanzee two hours after he fled from a zoo in northern Japan.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter From Africa: Revelations From Panama Papers Are Old News for Africans
item.description: Many in Africa have long known that billions of dollars are being spirited away to tax havens every year, making their lives even more precarious.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Khulubuse Zuma, a nephew of President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, is among the the African political elites cited in the Panama Papers.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan’s Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 3
item.description: The quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 6.4, damaged buildings, knocked out power and killed at least three people, according to Japanese news media.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: A collapsed wall in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, after a strong earthquake struck Japan on Thursday.

item.title: Iran’s President Is Squeezed by Opposition Leader’s Demand for a Trial
item.description: The request by the opposition leader, Mehdi Karroubi, who is under house arrest, highlighted a deepening rift in Iran’s reformist wing.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani on Thursday. The president has promised to end house arrest for Mehdi Karroubi and two other leaders of the reformist Green Movement.

item.title: Canadian Prime Minister Seeks to Legalize Physician-Assisted Suicide
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has introduced legislation to address the legal void left after Canada’s Supreme Court overturned a ban on doctor-assisted death.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada has said his support for doctor-assisted death was informed by the last days of his father, former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

item.title: Europe, in Wake of Attacks, Votes to Collect Air Passenger Data
item.description: Lawmakers approved the measure, which is backed by the United States, to establish a continentwide system to share information on travelers.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A security agent screened a passenger’s travel documents in Brussels last week. The data about travelers that the European Union hopes to begin sharing includes names, travel dates, itineraries and payment methods.

item.title: Europe’s Privacy Watchdogs Call for Changes to U.S. Data-Transfer Deal
item.description: The region’s national regulators say the so-called Privacy Shield agreement does not sufficiently protect their citizens’ rights.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We believe there’s still work to do,” Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, France’s data protection chief, who also heads a Pan-European regulatory privacy group, said on Wednesday.

item.title: In West Bank, Israel Imposes Pop-Up Checkpoints and Road Closings
item.description: The winding detours for drivers are focused on smaller areas and thus not drawing widespread outrage among Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: A road in Kharbata al-Misbah, one of several in the West Bank that have been repeatedly closed by Israel, forcing detours.

item.title: New York Times Plans International Digital Expansion
item.description: The company announced that it would invest $50 million on a strategy to increase its digital audience and revenue outside the United States.
item.dc:creator: SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: After South Korea Spurns Park Geun-hye, She May Press Agenda Abroad
item.description: The president’s party lost its majority, prompting speculation that she might bolster her relevance with a bold foreign policy move. What that might be was not clear.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Sorting ballots in a gymnasium in Seoul, South Korea. The Saenuri Party of President Park Geun-hye lost its majority in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Bolster Air and Sea Presence in South China Sea
item.description: The American defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, said the patrols were a response to China’s increasing assertiveness in the region.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: American Marines taking part in a joint military exercise in Capas, the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Approves New Prime Minister in Vote
item.description: Volodymyr B. Groysman replaced Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk in the most significant shuffle of the country’s senior leadership since a revolution two years ago.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: A Champion of Japan’s Right Wing Is Jailed Over Campaign Payments
item.description: Toshio Tamogami, a deeply conservative former military commander turned politician, is accused of making illegal payments to members of his staff.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Toshio Tamogami regularly endorses contentious policies like changing the antiwar Constitution to remove restrictions on the military. He has also asserted that Japan was duped into attacking Pearl Harbor in 1941.

item.title: A Champion of Japan’s Right Wing Is Jailed Over Campaign Payments
item.description: Toshio Tamogami, a deeply conservative former military commander turned politician, is accused of making illegal payments to members of his staff.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Toshio Tamogami regularly endorses contentious policies like changing the antiwar Constitution to remove restrictions on the military. He has also asserted that Japan was duped into attacking Pearl Harbor in 1941.

item.title: Sinosphere: Tiananmen Protest Museum Says It’s Being Forced Out of Hong Kong Location
item.description: The organizers of the museum, which claims over 20,000 visitors, say they will stop fighting a suit by the building’s owner and will seek a new spot.
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: A man walking past a display at a museum in Hong Kong dedicated to remembering the June 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, Labour Leader, Urges Britons to Vote to Stay in E.U.
item.description: Mr. Corbyn described the bloc as a crucial tool against climate change and tax evasion, saying there was a “strong socialist case” for remaining.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, Britain’s opposition Labour Party leader, spoke about the county’s membership in the European Union in London on Thursday.

item.title: Editorial Observer: In Paris, a Protest Movement Awakens
item.description: Students are rising up against the existing political and economic order.
item.dc:creator: MIRA KAMDAR
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at Place de La Republique in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Death of Liberalism
item.description: Authoritarianism is ascendant and with it anti-rational bigotry. History does not end. It eddies.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Search Goes On for Nigerian Girls Kidnapped by Boko Haram, 2 Years Later
item.description: The mass abduction, on April 14, 2014, was just one of hundreds of acts of brutality that Boko Haram has rained down on West Africa in recent years.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Bring Back Our Girls movement gathered in Lagos on Wednesday for a rally calling for the release of Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.
